prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.

spanGrp.span: How do we make the ‘fruit leather’ (bastīg) and the infaraḏ̣a here? The women bring, let’s say, they bring the pots, the big pots.
They bring them and they put grape jelly and starch in them; wheat starch, sugar and a little bit of flour.
They put them (in the pots) and (then) they put water on them. They keep stirring them; they give them on the fire and keep stirring and stirring, which takes a lot of effort.
Keep stirring them until it holds itself, until it becomes like paluze (a kind of pudding); until it thickens.
After it has thickened, ah, but keep on stirring it as much as you can stir in order that it does not burn because then it gets a taste of …
When the sugar burns it would have a burnt taste in it and it would stick (on the pot). Therefore, you keep stirring it.
Like, when you keep stirring it, you keep stirring it until it is ready and thickens;
Then you put it aside to cool down. Then you put it on the trays; you take it out either with the scoop or with the hand. You keep emptying (it) onto the trays.
And you let that what you empty on the trays like this until it cools down. You let it cool and then you cut it into pieces. This is called infaraḏ̣a.
You let it until it firms up; it firms up in the tray and than you take it out piece by piece and put some starch on it.
You put wheat starch on it and keep spreading it. You spread it on newspapers or you spread it on pieces of cloth. This is the infaraḏ̣a and that one is the bastīg.
For the bastīg, you bring a large piece of white fabric. You open the fabric cloth and you take it out, you keep doing the same, you take it out and pour it onto the thingy.
You keep spreading it; you spread it like this, like the thingy. You keep spreading it, on one thingy, on one level, and one you make it like pita bread.
You keep spreading it until the the fabric cloth has got filled and then you put in on the roofs or in the courtyard. You keep spreading it until everyting is full.
You spread it; you keep moving and spreading it like this. You keep spreading it, let’s say, very thin, I mean it does not even reach one centimetre.
Very thin, some millimetres, millimetres; like (pita) bread. Afterwards, when it has firmed up, the (dry) air has an effect on it.
And so it firms up; and then you start bringing starch and you keep sprinkling starch on it; and you keep making it wet. You sprinkle it the first time with water. You sprinkle it with water.
Until it comes off. You sprinkle the bottom of the cloth and then you flip the cloth like this and make it wet; you sprinkle it like you sprinkle the bread.
If it does not come off, when it sticks on it because it contains sugar, sugar and sweetness and so on; if it sticks, you sprinkle it like this.
Then it comes off; when the cloth comes off from the thingy, the bastīg, I mean,
You keep turning it like this on each side and you keep putting some starch on it. But this cannot be done at all times.
If they make it in summer, it becomes hard like plastic and it cannot be eaten; and if you have made it, when you make it in autumn, in autumn it becomes soft and so it can be eaten.
Then you take it and keep putting it in the sun, into the autumn sun, because it is not too hot.
You put it (in the sun) until you see that it has dried; then you take it and you keep it as a stock; as a food which is for the winter.
You keep putting starch on it and you take it and put it in the... either in a box or a jar. And then you store it.
